1ln.title: Arbital requisites
1ln.clickbait: To understand a thing you often need to understand some other things.

1lw.title: Mathematics
1lw.clickbait: Mathematics is the study of numbers and other ideal objects that can be described by axioms.

1lz.title: Bayes' rule
1lz.clickbait: Bayes' rule is the core theorem of probability theory saying how to revise our beliefs when we make a new observation.

1r5.title: Math 1
1r5.clickbait: Is math sometimes fun for you, and are you not anxious if you see a math puzzle you don't know how to solve?

1rf.title: Probability
1rf.clickbait: The degree to which someone believes something, measured on a scale from 0 to 1, allowing us to do math to it.

1rt.clickbait: Arbital path is a linear sequence of pages tailored specifically to teach a given concept to a user.

1wy.title: Waterfall diagram

1x1.title: Waterfall and frequency diagrams: Intro (Math 1)
1x1.clickbait: Waterfalls and frequency diagrams.  Part of the Bayes Intro sequence.
1x1.text:
From the example problems page:

> You are screening a set of patients for a disease, which we'll call Diseasitis.  You expect that around 20% of the patients in the screening population start out with Diseasitis.  You are testing for the presence of the disease using a sensitized tongue depressor.  Among patients with Diseasitis, 90% turn the tongue depressor black.  However, 30% of the patients without Diseasitis will also turn the tongue depressor black.  Among all the patients with black tongue depressors, how many have Diseasitis?

Two streams of water, a red stream and a blue stream, separately approach the top of the waterfall and fall into a pool below.

![unlabeled waterfall](https://i.imgur.com/D8EhY65.png?0)

Suppose that at the top of the waterfall, there's around 20% red water and 80% blue water.  As both streams of water fall, some water is diverted away to the sides, such that only 90% of the red water and 30% of the blue water reaches the bottom pool.  Of the purplish water that mixes in the pool, what fraction is from the red stream versus the blue stream?

This problem is isomorphic to the Diseasitis problem at the top of this page:  "20% of the patients in a screening population have Diseasitis.  90% of the patients with Diseasitis turn the tongue depressor black, and 30% of the patients without Diseasitis turn the tongue depressor black.  How many patients that turn the tongue depressor black have Diseasitis?"

The 20% of the patients with Diseasitis, and 80% patients without Diseasitis, are represented by the red versus blue streams at the top of the waterfall:

![top labeled waterfall](https://i.imgur.com/eQh2qUt.png?0)

The 90% of patients with Diseasitis who turn the tongue depressor black, and 30% of patients without Diseasitis who turn the tongue depressor black, correspond to the amounts of the red versus blue water that make it into the bottom pool:

![middle labeled waterfall](https://i.imgur.com/6GBBYO5.png?0)

And the question of how many patients in the 'turned the tongue depressor black' pool actually have Diseasitis, is the same as the question of how what percentage of water in the bottom pool originally came from the red stream.

There's an obvious way to solve the Diseasitis problem, and a fast and sneaky way to solve it.  We'll do the harder way first.

We start by imagining a population of 100 patients, of whom 20 have Diseasitis and 80 don't.

![prior frequency](https://i.imgur.com/gvcoqQN.png?0)

(This is called a "frequency visualization".  Out there in the rest of the world where not everyone is great at math, multiple studies show that talking about 20 patients produces better problem-solving ability than talking about 20% of patients.)

We then proceed to put black halos on 9 out of 10 sick patients and 3 out of 10 healthy patients.  This produces 90% * 20 = 18 sick patients with black tongue depressors, and 30% * 80 = 24 healthy patients with black tongue depressors.

![posterior frequency](https://i.imgur.com/0XDbrYi.png?0)

To get the probability back out, we say that there are 18 sick patients with black tongue depressors, within a total population of 18 + 24 = 42 patients total who have black tongue depressors.  So the final answer is that a patient with a black tongue depressor has an 18/42 = 43% probability of being sick.

Now for the fast and sneaky way of doing the calculation.  We start with *4 times as much blue water as red water* at the top of the waterfall.  Then 90% of the red water and 30% of the blue water make it to the bottom, which means that each particle of red water is *three times as likely* as a particle of blue water to make it to the bottom.  So we multiply a ratio of 1 : 4 by a ratio of 3 :  1 and end up with a ratio of 3 : 4, meaning that the bottom pool has 3 parts of red water to 4 parts of blue water.

![labeled waterfall](https://i.imgur.com/QIrtuVU.png?0)

If we want to convert 3 parts red water to 4 parts blue water into a percentage of total water that is red, we just calculate 3/(3 + 4) or 43%.

3 : 4, of course, is just the same as the ratio of 18 to 24 (sick patients with positive test results versus healthy patients with positive test results).  So to solve the Diseasitis problem in your head, you would convert this word problem:

"20% of the patients in a screening population have Diseasitis.  90% of the patients with Diseasitis turn the tongue depressor black, and 30% of the patients without Diseasitis turn the tongue depressor black.  How many patients that turn the tongue depressor black have Diseasitis?"

To this calculation:

"Okay, so the initial odds are (20 : 80) = (1 : 4), the likelihoods are (90 : 30) = (3 : 1), multiplying gives final odds of (3 : 4) and that's a probability of 3/7."

Now reconsider the following problem, if you haven't already solved it:

> 10% of widgets are bad and 90% are good.  4% of good widgets emit sparks, and 12% of bad widgets emit sparks.  Can you calculate in your head what percentage of sparking widgets are bad?

For the answer, [1td click or hover here].

22s.title: Diseasitis
22s.clickbait: 20% of patients have Diseasitis. 90% of sick patients and 30% of healthy patients turn a tongue depressor black. You turn a tongue depressor black. What's the chance you have Diseasitis?

3d.clickbait: Arbital is the place for crowdsourced, intuitive math explanations.

3hs.clickbait: How to write intuitive, flexible content on Arbital.

3n.clickbait: Parent-child relationship between pages implies a strong, inseparable connection.
